Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide â€œcomfortâ€ services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding â€œcomfort womenâ€ regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the â€œcomfort womenâ€ who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: That's a very circular argument you make there. It boils down to: "Our laws are legitimate because they are made by our government. Our government is legitimate because our laws say it is legitimate." The question is, what constitutes legitimacy? It's not voting per se. Mubarak regularly got over 90% of the vote. So did Saddam Hussein. Not many would call their elections legitimate. 

I'm not comparing our elections to theirs. But we're talking about the legitimacy of the laws that emanate from a given electoral system. In an ideal sense a law may not be considered fully legitimate until there is consensus on it. That's obviously not going to happen with millions of voters, so the question is, how do we move closer to true legitimacy? An honestly counted FPTP is obviously closer than a corrupt system. But we can do much better than FPTP which has some very serious flaws for a modern technological society.

Comment: 2-" What is the relationship between the tribes and the individual states?

Because the Constitution vested the Legislative Branch with plenary power over Indian Affairs, states have no authority over tribal governments unless expressly authorized by Congress. While federally recognized tribes generally are not subordinate to states, they can have a government-to-government relationship with these other sovereigns, as well. 

Furthermore, federally recognized tribes possess both the right and the authority to regulate activities on their lands independently from state government control.  They can enact and enforce stricter or more lenient laws and regulations than those of the surrounding or neighboring state(s) wherein they are located. Yet, tribes frequently collaborate and cooperate with states through compacts or other agreements on matters of mutual concern such as environmental protection and law enforcement. "
https://www.bia.gov/frequently-asked-questions

Comment: This article reminds me of how much we USED to enjoy exploring all the sea life in the many tide pools and low-tide beaches of Kachemak Bay.  Sadly, in the last 10 or 15 years most of that sea life, and those low-tide invertebrates, have disappeared, most especially the shellfish, due to the population explosion among the sea otters which the Center for Coastal Studies still refuses to acknowledge.  Low tide around Chugachik Island last year, for example, only exposed tidal flats that resemble an artillery range, as the formerly abundant clam beds have been eliminated by all the sea otters who have desperately dug them up almost to the last clam, leaving gaping holes in the process.

The wide diversity and abundance of intertidal sea life in Kachemak Bay is, for now anyway, mostly just a memory, and will remain so until something happens, or steps are taken, to reduce the extreme overpopulation of sea otters in those waters.

Comment: The Seward Hwy has been extensively changed for the better over that past several decades Don. The Bird to Gird realignment, the widening from Bird to South of Potter by Wilder Construction in the early '80s and prior to that the widening and straightening by Kiewitt from Potter to where Wilder's started. That's a lot of miles of effort and does not even include the more recent pull outs for slow vehicles. Further south the highway has been totally realigned and widened up through Turnagain Pass and again through the Granite Creek area and on up to Summit Lake. Passing lanes, lots more turnouts and wider aprons on the sides. The only stretch of the Seward highway that is still "unchanged for decades" is from Moose Pass south to Snow River because beyond that the road over 12 mile hill has been upgraded with passing lanes as well. Criticizing is fine and I understand your concerns but hundreds of millions have been spent on modernizing the Seward Hwy. One project at a time.

I am not advocating removing CMHSC, just lowering the max house price say 750k and making banks shoulder 10% of those mortgages too. The point of CMHSC is to give Canadians a chance at housing and to stabilise the market, not absolve banks of risk (thanks Flaherty!). 

There is no real free housing market in Canada, especially when outside money obtained by quesitonable means also has no restrictions in Canada's market!

Comment: The strong dollar is a problem, as the article says. While it lets us get a discount on goods made overseas, it makes US companies less competitive internationally. Nearly 80% of my company's business is international and the strong dollar has made customers complain about the rising cost (from their perspective) even though pricing has held steady. If I assembled iPhones in China then it would even out--cheaper for me to make so I could price lower. But since what we do is all done in the US, and most of our supply chain is in the US, the strong dollar is all downside.

Iâ€™m not sure I understand the reference to land.  Increasingly power generation will be distributed, sited on homes and businesses. Comment: In much of the developed world (i.e. the OECD) inflation-targeting has been the core objective of monetary policy ever since inflation laid waste to government planning and projections when it degenerated into the stagflation of the 1970s when growth stalled and  inflation ballooned out past 20%. This erodes savings and investment and it encourages borrowing and spending. The $20000 object which you borrowed to buy today (at 20% interest p.a over 5 years) was likely to cost you $100 000 cash in 5 years time, so it made sense to borrow now. Besides, you'd probably get double-digit pay-increases every year anyway, so the principal you'd borrowed was shrinking as a percentage of your income.
Today OECD nations have reined in inflation so well (sitting around 1% p.a.) that they are now in danger of slipping into an even more destructive force: deflation. SA's inflation (near 7%) is still way too high to worry about deflation, so it needs to be hauled down lower.

Comment: Your accusations that "Bailey went out of his way to find a church [with] bigoted and retrograde doctrine" and that Bailey is tolerant of misogyny and homophobia are baseless, and I believe are directly contradicted by the excerpt I quoted. 

Being tolerant of an organization whose principles you publicly disavow is not the same as being tolerant of those principles. This isn't cognitive dissonance; this is having the ability to navigate a world in which people and organizations aren't black-and-white all-good or all-evil. 

If we're going to assert that Bailey is unfit to lead, let's do so based on his qualifications, including his actual words and actions. In particular, given that his actual words and actions have expressed a disapproval of the intolerant aspects of his church, I think it's actively dishonest and distracting to accuse Bailey of "probably" holding those principles himself. That's like saying HRC is "probably an adulteress" just because she never divorced Bill.

As a public sector employee, I find myself getting very defensive at the insinuation that I am lazy or am a drain on our society. I am, however, also disgusted at the obstructionist games that public administrators play in order to keep their budgets, often at the expense of efficiency. I completely understand why people roll their eyes when folks in the government cry, "the sky is falling". The rhetoric is largely short-sighted and selfish: cut the government but invest in oil (so I can keep my job), tax the evil oil companies (so I can keep my job). Comment: Except the two aren't the same.  The house is a tangible asset traceable to the proceeds of the crime.  While the degree may be traceable to to the crime, it's not a tangible asset.  If someone steals something (and by something, I mean a tangible, identifiable piece of property), then I'm all for ordering that it be returned.  But when a child is brought into this country by their parents, their presence here isn't like a piece of property, it's much more like the college education.  It's an intangible, ephemeral concept that can't easily be divorced from the person who possesses it.   

And worth noting that in most cases, the house wouldn't be seized.  If there was a crime of violence, there could be a lien against the property, but it wouldn't be an eviction of the children living there.

Comment: I agree with you completely. Ten years ago my father had a massive hemorrhagic stroke and was kept alive during that day until I could get to the hospital. Comment: This is the most over capitalized distressed sector in history.  There is about a US$1 trillion that is either a pure play on energy, or part of a diversified fund.  The money is roughly 30% PE, 30% mezz and 40% senior secured.

Huge integrated teams exist.  Special access to anything but $1 to $5 million deals will not exist, so no real local edge either.  Couple this with baseline uncertainty as to the price of a barrel of crude or natural gas and you have the makings of a very disappointing sector from a return perspective....unless.....of course energy prices rally hard in which case the better play was long financial derivatives without the operational risk and illiquidity.

Asset management is a scale game.  It is not a boutique business for the inexperienced any more. $400 million funds are simply too small for best practices from a governance and regulatory perspective and too big for a couple of sweat heart deals with pals...think Athabaska Trust.  This is no man's land.

Comment: I'm convinced that too many people, especially who comment here, are weighed down with anger, hurt, or have other axes to grind against the Catholic Church. The result is a loss of objectivity and balance.

What does this report tell us:

- Lots of allegations from the past, including fairly far back (1940s), were brought foward -- mostly by lawyers, in the wake of a law inviting new submissions. Common sense tells you to be leery of these.

- The number of new accusations is very small: 25. Of these, almost half are "unsubstantiated." Two have been substantiated, the rest are still being looked into. All these were reported to civil authorities.

- An interesting detail if you read further on page 19: much of what the report lumps together as "child sexual abuse" turns out, upon closer examination, to be  "more of a boundary issue and not sexual abuse." 

Only for someone truly embittered is this a bad report.

Comment: Of course, getting a  head start is not discrimination. It is what you do with that head start. 
Say you are in a 100 metre dash with 10 competitors, You and 8 others get a 20 metre head start. When the one person who didn't get the head start finishes last,  you don't blame his last place finish on his genetic inferiority, or that he didn't train hard enough and is lazy.
He probably came in last because the other competitors were way ahead to begin with.
And if you believe in having a fair race -- giving him/her an equal chance to win -- you would even out the starting blocks for the next race.
It's that simple.

Comment: "...carbon capture and sequestration. These methods are already being developed and deployed around the world"

Comment: There is a point of diminishing returns on additional bike facilities.    There are those that will ride bicycles and those that will not.   In my age group among my friends I'm the only one who frequently rides.  Eugene is by no means devoid of bike lanes, off street paths, short cuts, and bike racks, but  bike use is still limited by weather,  fear of nighttime riding, ability to carry things,  distances to be covered with the time available.     I do not see a rental bike scheme greatly adding to the number of bike trips for these reasons.    Those that are prone to riding a bike already have a privately owned one and use it.   I would prefer to see a two year trial of the rental project and then a totally unbiased analysis of its effectiveness.   If it does not measure up to predetermined objective standards, discontinue it and reclaim as much of the taxpayers' contribution as possible.

Trade between 2 independent countries, on the one hand, and between 2 Provinces or States of a Federation or a Customs Union, on the other hand, is generally quite distinct on this point. Comment: When I was growing up Denver Academy cost $22,000 a year. Kent Denver was more expensive and Denver Christian and Saint Mary's were around $15,000. Title I money is meant to help schools that face the challenge of educating a lot of poor students; making it portable means some federal money would also go to schools that are generally wealthy but enroll a handful of kids from poor families. But turning Title I into vouchers wouldnâ€™t be enough on its own to start a private school exodus. Dividing $14 billion in federal funding among the 25 million students poor enough to count as â€œdisadvantagedâ€ yields a voucher of $580. Private school tuition costs, on average, nearly $11,000 per year.

Comment: Eric, the point is that with rail we may or may not eliminate Honolulu's traffic congestion, but without it, we definitely won't. The ridership numbers in the EIS are irrelevant. Actual ridership will depend a lot on what other land use and transportation policies the City implements.  That being said, we are building the right kind of system if we want to maximize ridership and land use impacts.  A great comparison is to look at what Portland and Vancouver did over the last 30 years. The 2 cities are almost exactly the same size (pop = 600k city, 2.3 million metro), but Portland build at-grade light rail and Vancouver built grade-separated metro rail.  Both cities' first rail line was built at the same time (1985 & 1986). The impact has been very different. Daily rail ridership: Portland 116,000, Vancouver 390,000. Daily transit ridership: Portland 320,000, Vancouver 1.25 million. Auto mode share: Portland 67%, Vancouver 41%. Transit mode share: Portland 11.8%, Vancouver 24%.

For example, the EPA report cites studies that have linked fracking and the contamination of drinking water resources in instances where companies spilled fracking fluids, experienced equipment failure or fracked wells too close in depth to drinking water resources (i.e., shallow fracking), for example.
 the federal government canâ€™t regulate fracking, including chemical disclosure, because of a provision in the Energy Policy Act of 2005. This act was preceded by a 2001 energy policy report that advocated for the expanded use of fracking and was released by a group chaired by Cheney. Comment: No, I'm against mob rule. Related, I'm also against any activity that violates others' rights.  Such activity would include forcible interference in the voluntary associations between individuals, and in the voluntary exchanges of goods and services between individuals.  If something is wrong for me to do (like taking your wallet or forcing you to put a garden on your roof), then it's wrong for any number of people to do - even if it's sanctioned by the govt. This means I'm for the individual's right to their own life (and all derivative "rights" like property). Force is only appropriate in protecting rights.  It's not appropriate for some "ends justify the means" alleged good cause.

Comment: Saunders makes the statement that living standards in most western countries have not declined and that in fact we are now better off. 
When I came to BC in 1972, my first (unskilled) job earned me $4.25 cents an hour. I quickly found a better paying job at 5.25 to pay my way through University. Jobs were plentiful. At that time, a standard 3 Bedroom house at Main and 33rd cost $34,000.00. At today's rate of inflation, of 5.85 times 1972, that would mean that my very first job was about $25.00 an hour and after three months I was being paid about $31.00 hour. That house at 33rd and Main would cost under $200,000.00. Todays 19 year olds are actually making about $10.00 an hour (if they can find a job) and that house would sell for more than $1.5 million. 
This country has declined drastically. Doug Saunders and the other champagne socialists can continue to pretend otherwise. No wonder people voted for Trump.

Comment: Stephan Paliwoda: I agree of course with the gist of your comments. But please note that Donald Trump is NOT president "because of the unequal distribution of electoral votes among the states" but rather because almost all states have chosen -- for partisan advantage -- to give ALL their electoral votes to the popular vote winner in their own state.

One could take this as indicating that the NATIONAL popular vote should instead be used, but an alternative is to recognize that this practice unconstitutionally deprives minority voters in each state of equal protection (i.e., equal treatment of their votes), an issue that was highlighted by the Supreme Court in Bush v. Gore (2000). 

A solution would be for all states to agree to assign their electoral votes proportionally to the popular vote in their own state. If this were done -- even with the small-state advantage built into the Electoral College -- Trump would still have lost (given the campaigns and votes as they were).

Comment: I think there is a whole other scenario which needs debating under this heading.  That is the proliferation of large shopping centres in SA dominated by an anchor tenant which is typically one of these retailers.  Not only do their lease agreements shut out competition in that specific shopping centre, it also devastates the smaller community based grocery retailers within a 5km radius.  So although the retailers do provide significant employment in SA, the question is to what extent does this replace owner-businesses, whose direct impact in their communities is much more positive that the employee-based large retailer.  The uncompetitive practices imposed by the shopping centres and retailers should be the subject of an academic study and whose findings should impact on any decision to develop yet another large shopping centre.

Comment: As a dealer in precious metals,our business tests every gold bar  and coin that passes through our store . Comment: I have seen several petitions in the past three months that have resulted in action taken by the Federal Regulators, guess what, Congressional action was not involved nor sought.  Well written petitions and comments can have an effect on rulemaking, I should know as I had to write and evaluate regulations and comments.  Congress passes laws but it is the Executive Branch that writes the regulations to conform with the enacted Public Law.  Often in determining Congressional Intent on a Public Law , it is necessary to go into the hearing records for a particular law.  The EIS is an action taken by any agency when they determine that an EIS is needed or has been requested.  It is all done in accordance with the requirements as stipulated by National Environmental Protection Act (NEPA).

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

First off, the majority of TABOR is a disaster.

I do have to say that I would like to see us remove all of the rest of TABOR. We need to quit returning money, and instead, require a bank for it. And I am thinking that we should follow N. Dakota's path and create a colorado bank with it.

Comment: LW1 - are they really concerned with the look of the neighborhood or is it something else?  I think it's something else, whether it's religious or just someone's fetish to hate on holloween. Comment: That is a good point. Language does change and "begs the question" is assuming legitimacy from the increased use, replacing "raises the question". Try hanging out with some street people in New York and see how well one can speak their language and be accepted.

In other words, it says the statement "begs" the question generated by the questioner.  But how can a statement beg a question? Maybe it doesn't.

Comment: Overall, this was a good article, but I have to disagree with the author that income sprinkling is somehow justified.  It is not, simple as that.  Employees do not have the ability to sprinkle income to other family members, so why should a business owner? Full disclosure, I own two businesses and yes, I do what is legal under the current tax rules.  I also get business risk, believe me, but they are two totally unrelated issues.  You should own and run a business because the risk/return relationship is favourable.  You don't own a business with the expectation of the govt supporting your feasibility by allowing the owner to sprinkle income to kids.  It's not just doctors, it is also lawyers, accountants, business owners of private companies, etc..  The govt doesn't owe you a special tax break that others don't get (deferred income).  The govt shouldn't allow you expense deductions that others don't get (i.e. write off phone bills, home office, car usage, meals, computers, etc..).

Comment: The "methane boils out of the tundra and cooks the earth" meme was debunked in 2011 by the U.S.G.S.  Two lines of evidence:  One was a numerical simulation that failed to demonstrate runaway hydrate melting (Live by the Computer Model; Fall by the Computer Model); the second is observation of the geologic/ice core record that fails to show any huge methane spikes or wholesale permafrost melting in any of the (numerous) interglacials we've had previously, that were just as warm as anything predicted for the rest of the 21st Century.  See this reference:  Ruppel, C. D. (2011), "Methane Hydrates and Contemporary Climate Change", in _Nature Education Knowledge_ 3(10):29.

Comment: No doubt a lot of electricity will come from fossil sources in the near future.  Your F150 can't refuel itself sitting in a sunny parking lot while you're at work, but an EV can sit under a solar panel awning and be juiced by when it's time to head home.  Or it can recharge from hydropower (note: your F150 cannot).

The grid of the (near) future will be driven as much by storage as by generation.  A parking lot full of 200 EVs represents a giant battery for grid stability and peak load matching and storing intermittent renewable energy.  Same goes for the fixed storage systems that are coming online.  Your utility will become a storage manager.  

In the US electricity usage over the last decade dropped by 2.5% even as our GDP rose by 10%.  Efficiency continues to be the best investment, and it's only accelerating.

The energy world is changing, my friend.  Not overnight, but definitely for your kids and grandkids.  What kind of economy do you want to pass on to them?

Comment: Such certainty with so few facts. The City of London is unlikely to face the devastation you suggest for three reasons - tax, currency and human resources. The first two will continue to be firmly within the UK's control. Brussels, Frankfurt and Paris may be salivating over the financial possibilities of Brexit, yet none of these destinations offer the quality of life found in London. And will the big financial players want to move all their assets when there is such residual risk of further defections from and ultimate demise of the EU? Singapore on Thames anyone? 

Concerning Scotland, North Sea oil is dying. The cost to remove and remediate the platforms and undersea structures is a minimum of 20 billion sterling (roughly $CAD 33 billion) that will largely be financed by the exchequer as tax refunds. Hardly a jewel in any crown - British or Scottish.

Comment: Good in principle but we'll need to see how it works in practice. We don't have tariffs of course, but we have numerous non-tarrif barriers including subsidies, preference policies, regulatory differences, licensing requirements and marketing boards. 

The devil may be in the details - the mechanisms for challenging barriers, determining injury, and enforcing decisions. What protections, for example, will exist for smaller provinces whose cottage industries could be wiped out by the equivalent of dumping? 

Based on the most recent pipeline controversy in western Canada, we can assume energy is on the negative list. Provinces like B.C. and Quebec will still be able to exact a heavy toll on the transmission of energy through their provinces - if they allow it at all. How big a benefit will it be that pigs feet can cross provincial boundaries unmolested when oil and electricity cannot? Chicken feed?

Comment: Johann Zenger wrote: "except, of course, one can use TOR, VPN software, and encryption without cost."  

It takes two parties agreeing to use many of the security solutions available (sender and receiver).  I use all of the methods you mention but I am aware that there are ways around many, if not all, of those protections.  What is required is some spine on the part of our government to create laws that make it a crime for a host of issues that are currently ignored; when there are legal consequences for violating my privacy the security environment will likely improve.  There should be severe legal penalties, for example, when my insurance company loses data about me to thieves using The Internet to break into the company servers.  Penalties and the possibility of civil suits would go a long way to forcing companies holding information from/about me and offering communications services to protect MY data.  Heck, until recently ACS didn't even provide simple SSL for email logins.

Comment: Becca:

You make a good point about stores potentially losing customers who are turned off by having obviously fraudulent service animals running around their stores.

I am sure that most store owner/managers would love to be able to do something about this problem.  

But, under the current "wild west" regulatory environment there are really no good options for businesses to deal with the problem.  Businesses can ask an offender to take the animal outside.  But, they risk a civil rights claim which they first of all have to epend time and money to defend, even if they are right and prevail.  And, second they face the risk of making a mistake and literaly being fined or sued out of business.   

Most businesses lack the expertise to deal with these situations under the current regulatory environment.

Comment: Its not that simple, Jennifer.  If it were, China with 4 times the US population would not enjoy the largest trade surplus in history ($360 billion US in 2015) with the US.

Yes, population and purchasing power are factors but the biggest factors are the value of goods and services the respective countries need from each other and the access each country allows the other to its market.

Canada and the US are a wash on balance of trade.  We have a slight surplus when resources prices are highest and they often have a slight surplus with us due to high ticket, high tech exports.  I expect that the Canada-US arrangements will only be tweaked.

Mexico - US trade is the problem.  DJT wants to reduce the continuing trade deficit with Mexico exceeding $50 billion a year.  Incentivizing-coercing US firms to return lost production (and jobs!) to the US and expand 1st in the US is his aim.  Impossible to predict how this will play out between Mexico and the US but DJT has the stronger hand.

Comment: This is about tribal membership and jurisdiction over members , not some larger notion of how much Native one might be and whether a tribe could reach out and take over jurisdiction of a non-enrolled child.
Under federal law tribes determine by explicit rules who may be enrolled in their tribe.
"... tribal nations use a variety of criteria in determining their membership. These tools may be used in combination as well. For example, many tribes who use descendancy may also use blood quantum defined in terms of either tribal blood or Indian blood.  Others will combine parental residency requirements with descendancy."
http://genetics.ncai.org/tribal-sovereignty-and-enrollment-determinations.cfm
This does all get sticky when a child is an enrolled member and a parent is not. Though there is some case law which addresses the rights of that parent  , much is still being duked out there.

Comment: " It has no paved roads, formal street names or addresses â€” but has stunning views of Pearl Harbor and beyond."

"...Romy Mindo, who has largely given up farming his lot there because of difficulties in getting sufficient water."

The primary problem isn't failure to enforce ag zoning restrictions, it's that this parcel should not be zoned Ag1 in the first place. Nearly all of it is sloped/steeply sloped, gullied, rocky, dry, poor soil, inadequate water, no irrigation infrastructure. It's been officially designated inferior land for agriculture.  It cannot be profitably farmed, especially if owners/lessees have to pay to live elsewhere and commute back and forth on top of usual farming costs. This is the crux of the matter. 

If these working-class owners had the money and political connections of DR Horton or other developers, C&C would have assigned proper zoning a long time ago (small ag parcels with one dwelling allowed?). We need affordable housing and this land is good for that.

Comment: What I find curious about this topic is that water may get moved around, but it doesn't actually get "used up", i.e. it doesn't just disappear when used.  Pumping it from the aquifer to the surface for farming just moves it. A little goes into the vegetables that are shipped all over the world when harvested, but the rest either goes back into the ground, or gets evaporated into the atmosphere and eventually falls back to the ground as precipitation.

I'd like to see the article address that a bit more, telling us that the water isn't being used up but rather relocated.  And telling us a bit more of where it's being relocated to.

Comment: As the proud holder of a doctorate, with many good friends in the same category, I have a strong visceral attachment to higher education.  At the same time, the push for, and discussions about, higher education exist in a silo, separate from discussions about pension and retirement.

The facts are that we can't continue to push so hard for advanced education, sending people into the workforce at a later age, usually with substantial debt, and expect them to accomplish the sorts of savings in preparation for retirement in a noticeably shorter working life than their parents had.  The solution is not nudging pensionable age over by several years, since keeping older workers in the labor force longer crowds out younger people.   Demands for, and pursuit of, higher education is inextricably interwoven with the social institution of retirement.  We should not overlook that.

Comment: Glad I was finally able to see one of these marathon games.  As a lifelong baseball fan, it was fun to see all the quirks associated with a game that takes this long. I spent ten years working for a minor league club elsewhere and saw quite a bit - so I understand how difficult the process was for the Ems. You have to appreciate that it is still a professional baseball game and you can't lose sight of that fact despite a promotional firework event. Promotions are always secondary to the game itself, even though a lot of casual fans turn out due to promotions. No GM is forfeiting games for artificial reasons, that will only serve to deteriorate the relationships with the coaches, players and the parent ball club, not to mention the other club involved. Minor League baseball mirrors the structure of MLB, these aren't just amateur pick-up games despite the more casual, small-town, sometimes goofy entertainment vibe.

Comment: "Sacred" is an English word, and as with most western translations of Native Hawaiian concepts, is totally mangled by the European viewpoint.  The Native Hawaiians would say these places identified as "sacred" by the haole, that is, supernatural, is totally misconstrued. These are places of deep respect and reverence. Again, the English word "reverence" does not have anything to do with a supernatural religion like christianity or judaism. The word "reverence" is from the Latin "revereri", meaning "in great awe".  All the Native Hawaiians are saying is these places and objects are to be treated with respect and wonder, not the supernatural association being laid on them by a western mindset on what constitutes a "legitimate" religion.

Comment: I do not agree with you.

You state: "It's not a question of nature OR nurture, it's a matter of which one has a greater influence."

No. 

It might well be that the influence of each is EXACTLY 50-50, and for a moment let's assume it is that way, exactly like THAT.

The ACTUAL question is, given how the final result OF THAT on society may be that say 4% of men want to become programmers but only 2% of women want to become programmers, or say that 7% of women want to become doctors but only 4% of men want to become doctors, or that say 11% of women want to be kindergarten teachers but only 2% of men want to be kindergarten teachers, or that say 17% of men want to be heavy duty mechanics but only 3% of women want to do that...

... IS IT THEN fair, reasonable, logical or ethical to PUSH WITH POLICIES for ALL those workplaces to become as close to 50/50 men and women as possible?

THAT is the actual question at hand!

Comment: To call it "selfish" for an organism to reproduce is to remove all meaning of the word "selfish".

I mean, you can pretend that the yeast are selfish that make your beer, and that the bacteria are selfish that make your cheese.

But you might as well ascribe love or jealousy or revenge or guilt to said creatures.

Which is to say that the specific term "selfish" loses all meaning there.

As far as people go, it is ridiculous to label all human parents throughout history as selfish, unless somehow your definition of "unselfish" is to seek the eradication of all humans from existence. Many humans have been happy and content to have just one or two kids, which is in keeping with mere replacement levels for the species.

There is nothing intrinsically selfish about wanting to keep a species alive, be it your own species or another. You might as well call animal rescuers, of hippos and whales, as terribly selfish (roll eyes) for trying to keep those species in existence on the planet.

Comment: All our roadways are getting busier. A small part of this is caused by so many former cyclists who have returned to their cars (30% since 2009). However, our population is growing and the long decline in per capita miles driven reversed itself five years ago, so we have more people, more of those people are driving and those drivers are driving more miles.

Unfortunately, unless we take steps to make other means of transportation more inviting, we know where this ends: complete congestion. After we gridlock our roads, the political price to take back space for transportation choices that move people more efficiently will be higher, but at some point we will have to bite the bullet. Hopefully by then we will have transportation planners and other city staff who do a better job than they currently do.

Comment: It's a cultural thing.....litter that is.  In Japan, there is no plastic bag ban.  Stores will often charge 3-10 yen (about 3-10 cents) per plastic bag only upon request.  The thing is, most consumers will bring their own cloth bags and if they do get a plastic bag, you will never see them flying loose on the streets or beaches.  In fact, you will hardly see ANY litter of any kind at all.  They have come to realize that their country has few natural resources, so recycling is a MUST.  You will find it difficult to even find simple trash cans in public areas because you are supposed to recycle everything.  If you cannot find a trash can, you take your trash home to separate into recycle bins.  I don't see Hawaii people (or Americans in general) ever getting to that point, unfortunately!

Comment: "row through Marten's Rapids on McKenzie River near Vida. Marten's is considered a Class III rapid.."
Yes, but is it Marten's or Martin?  Is it named for an animal or Rev. T.M. Martin, first settler there, first Postmaster at Gate Creek (now Vida),  and controversial Baptist minister?  
The government and the RG say "Marten," based on early 20th century maps; I say "Martin" (or Martin's or Martins) based on experts and19th century evidence.
In  "Tales of the Oregon Cascades", legendary McKenzie River guide Prince Helfrich wrote  "When  Martin Rapids was reached, the boat was lined around it.  It was not until about 1924 that daring guides started running the rapids, and then it was without passengers." (p.17) 
 The leading expert on McKenzie River place names is Gerald W.Â Williams, who for years was a historian and sociologist for the USFS.  In his Oregon Encyclopedia articles  Williams consistently uses Martin Rapids.  I'd encourage the RG and others to check him out.

Comment: You said "However, the law states that a driver must yield right-of-way to the pedestrian any time a person is waiting to cross the street." 

This is true at a marked, or unmarked crosswalk (an intersection) but not everywhere along the road 

RCW 46.61.240 says "Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway." 

Pedestrians should be aware of this, and not just walk out in front of vehicles anywhere on the road, assuming they always have he right of way.

Comment: My dad took me on a supply tug boat to one of the drilling platforms years ago. We had to follow cracks in the ice for well over an hour to get 2 miles. The tug nosed into the platform and hooked doubled 50 ton nylon rope to one of the legs. Hoist rope lowered on the deck and they began lifting cargo off. I was forward watching when captain yelled over the com system to "hit the deck". A large pan of ice had sliced in half and was coming back together squeezing the tug. Ice against steel is an awful noise. Flat on deck the rope snapping like dynamite & the hook hit the bow. Then the tug started going backwards engines roaring as they hit full throttle. My dad had unhooked cargo net as all this was going on. The cargo hook got caught on his parka hood and lifted him up before it tore loose. After being pushed back for half mile we snaked through the cracks unloaded & returned to the dock. Where the hook had snapped back from the leg & hit the tug was a dent 1" deep. Never forgot.
